title: Ultra-High Energy Resolution EELS Beyond Room Temperature
content: Sample temperature is a key parameter in most materials science experiments. In scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM), the available range of operating temperatures has typically been confined to a range from about 100 K to 1500 K, and only a small subset of available tools enable significant cooling and heating in the same experimental session [1]. Efforts to cool below 100 K have been hampered by the availability of instrumentation suited to the task, and the applications have been limited to a relatively small set of so-called “hero experiments” where achieving a certain temperature sample was among the central challenges of the experiment [2].
